This is a pivotal moment between President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump in their rematch for the nationï¿½s highest office. Each will make his case to the American people with just over four months until Election Day.

Before we introduce them, we want to share the rules of the debate with the audience at home.
Former President Trump will be on the left side of the screen. President Biden will be appearing on the right. A coin toss determined their positions.
Each candidate will have two minutes to answer a question, and one minute each for responses and rebuttals. An additional minute for follow-up, clarification or response is at the moderatorsï¿½ discretion.
BASH:  When itï¿½s time for a candidate to speak, his microphone will be turned on and his opponentï¿½s microphone will be turned off. Should a candidate interrupt when his microphone is muted, he will be difficult to understand for viewers at home.
At the end of the debate, each candidate will get two minutes for closing statements.
There is no studio audience tonight. Pre-written notes, props or contact with campaign staff are not permitted during the debate.
By accepting our invitation to debate, both candidates and their campaigns agreed to accept these rules.
TAPPER:  Now please welcome the 46th president of the United States, Joe Biden.

What do you say to voters who feel they are worse off under your presidency than they were under President Trump?
BIDEN:  You have to take a look at what I was left when I became president, what Mr. Trump left me.

I come from Scranton, Pennsylvania. I come from a household where the kitchen table ï¿½ if things werenï¿½t able to be met during the month was a problem. Price of eggs, the price of gas, the price of housing, the price of a whole range of things.
Thatï¿½s why Iï¿½m working so hard to make sure I deal with those problems. And weï¿½re going to make sure that we reduce the price of housing. Weï¿½re going to make sure we build 2 million new units. Weï¿½re going to make sure we cap rents, so corporate greed canï¿½t take over.
The combination of what I was left and then corporate greed are the reason why weï¿½re in this problem right now.
In addition to that, weï¿½re in a situation where if you had ï¿½ take a look at all that was done in his administration, he didnï¿½t do much at all. By the time he left, thereï¿½s ï¿½ things had been in chaos. There was (ph) literally chaos.
And so, we put things back together. We created, as I said, those (ph) jobs. We made sure we had a situation where we now ï¿½ we brought down the price of prescription drugs, which is a major issue for many people, to $15 for ï¿½ for an insulin shot, as opposed to $400. And the situation is making ï¿½ and weï¿½re going to make that available to everybody, to all Americans. So weï¿½re working to bring down the prices around the kitchen table. And thatï¿½s what weï¿½re going to get done.

President Trump?
